sentences: Sharissa Dawes (born August 21, 1975) is an American singer.
section: N/A

sentences: Born and raised in New York City's borough of Brooklyn, she began her musical career in the girl groups Triple Dose and 4Kast.
section: N/A

sentences: 4Kast released their 1998 debut album, Any Weather, which was promoted with the singles "Miss My Lovin'" and "I Tried".
section: N/A

sentences: After her time in the groups, Sharissa worked as a backing vocalist before she was discovered by Jimmy Henchman.
section: N/A

sentences: Her debut solo album, No Half Steppin' (2002), peaked at number 44 on the Billboard 200 chart.
section: N/A

sentences: Several of its songs appeared on other Billboard charts.
section: N/A

sentences: Sharissa was featured the soundtrack of the 2003 romantic comedy film, Love Actually.
section: N/A

sentences: Her second solo album, Every Beat of My Heart (2005), was only released in Japan.

sentences: Jimmy Henchman discovered Sharissa in November 2002.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002: No Half Steppin' ===

sentences: Her 2002 debut album, No Half Steppin', was released through Henchmen and Motown on February 26 of that year.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002: No Half Steppin' ===

sentences: Ayana Byrd of Vibe called its sound a "brand of gritty, hip hop-influenced R&B, and its lyrics revolve around tales of love, heartbreak, and independence"; according to Bryce Wilson, the album was inspired by 1970s music.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002: No Half Steppin' ===

sentences: Jason Birchmeier of AllMusic identified No Half Steppin' as part of Motown's attempt "to break new artists into the urban market", and the label was presenting Sharissa in a style similar to Mary J. Blige and Aaliyah.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002: No Half Steppin' ===

sentences: Other music critics also compared the singer to Blige.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002: No Half Steppin' ===

sentences: The album received mainly-positive reviews, although some criticized its production.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002: No Half Steppin' ===

sentences: It peaked at number 44 on the Billboard 200 chart on March 16, 2002 (remaining on the chart for 10 weeks), number seven on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums Billboard chart and number 44 on the Top Album Sales Billboard chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002: No Half Steppin' ===

sentences: Sharissa performed material from the album at the Blazin' Hip-Hop and R&B Concert in Pittsburgh on June 16, 2002, and released a mixtape version.

sentences: "Any Other Night"'s music video was "the story of a woman getting her groove back after being neglected by her man".

sentences: The single peaked at number 72 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart on April 6, 2002, remaining on the chart for 14 weeks.

sentences: It reached number 21 on the Adult R&B Songs Billboard chart, number 23 on the R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay, number 23 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs, and number 70 on the Radio Songs Billboard charts.
